Hi Elliott and Curran;

Elliott, I know how you feel and can sympathize wit=
h your frustration.  Unfortunately it is a part of the learning curve assoc=
iated with this hobby.

As far as the dealers go, many of the people who ha=
ve tables at shows are not dealers.  They are collectors who are upgrading =
their collections, just like you, in San Fran by selling pieces that have n=
othing left to teach them and buying new ones that they hope to learn from.=
  The majority of these people have the same limited knowledge selling thei=
r items as you did buying it.

I doubt if they had any intent to mislead yo=
u, they just did not know any better.  Unfortunately this is true in most i=
nstances.  The seller has very little idea as to what he or she is selling.=
  This in my experience this applies equally to blades that are gime, and f=
ittings that are less than what they may be demonstrated as.

The dealers w=
ho make their living buying and selling swords and fittings know exactly wh=
at they are selling, and if they should make a mistake, they will look afte=
r you.

Its all part of the learning curve.

John

age -----

  Curran,

  I apologize, I sometimes 'leap before l=
ooking'! There are very few 
  dealers that one must be careful of. Asking =
a lot of questions, 
  getting a lot of opinions is critical for my surviva=
l along with the 
  other 'newbees'. But, the dealer that sold me this piec=
e (19 & 20 
  photos)was not honest with me. I ask the right questions and =
got 
  incorrect answers. As I said, "I have learned from this experiance."=
 

  The Saotome has a Shakudo rim.

  Thank you very much,

  Elliott

  P=
S; I admit making an ass out of myself sometimes.....I hate when 
  that ha=
ppens.

dy knows it pains me to go through the process

nally good

n the process of papering them (slow process)and
  > deciding which to keep=
. I planned to let an auction
  > house sell them, but learned the auction =
houses get
  > their pound of flesh! Unless I give them over $100,000

f items... they take a greater % than any dealer I
  > know.
  > As the tsu=
ba come back from Japan, I'll just put
  > them out at Tampa sword show and=
 possibly Chicago--
  > but ultimately a few of them will probably end up w=
ith
  > a dealer.
  > 
  > So go easy on the dealers. Many are good people =
who
  > provide a service to buyers and sellers. There are 2
  > or 3 I cal=
l friend.
  > 
  > Curran
